title.value: Aligning artificial intelligence with climate change mitigation
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper and throughout the document.
title.quote: Aligning artificial intelligence with climate change mitigation

extractions.description: This paper presents a systematic framework to assess and shape the effects of AI and ML on climate change mitigation. It categorizes the impacts of ML on GHG emissions into three areas: compute-related, immediate application impacts, and system-level impacts. The paper aims to provide a roadmap for research, policy, and organizational action to align ML more closely with climate change strategies.

type.justification: The paper introduces a systematic framework to classify and assess the impacts of machine learning on greenhouse gas emissions, rather than conducting experiments or empirical investigations.
type.quote: We therefore introduce a systematic framework for describing MLâ€™s effects on GHG emissions, comprising three categories: (A) compute-related impacts, (B) immediate impacts of applying ML, and (C) system-level impacts.

name.justification: The paper discusses aligning artificial intelligence with climate change mitigation, which fits under environmental sustainability with AI as a tool for achieving these goals.
name.quote: Assessing and shaping the effects of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) on climate change mitigation demands a concerted effort across research, policy, and industry.

name.justification: One of the main focuses of the paper is on analyzing and forecasting the impacts of ML on greenhouse gas emissions.
name.quote: To explicitly and consistently account for ML in long-term climate and energy projections, and in the design of appropriate policies, the research community needs to develop a holistic and operational understanding of the different ways in which ML can positively and negatively impact climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies.

name.justification: The paper explores the impacts of machine learning algorithms on climate change strategies and how they can be aligned with these strategies.
name.quote: In particular, those impacts that are easiest to measure are likely not those with the largest effects. This can lead to challenges in terms of estimating macro-scale effects, picking up on underlying dynamics and trends, and prioritizing actions to align ML with climate strategies.

name.justification: ResNet-50 is explicitly mentioned as an example of a deep learning model used for image classification within the context of energy consumption.
name.quote: ResNet-50, a popular deep learning model for image classification, requires about 4 billion FLOPs (and 65 milliseconds) to map a 224x224 pixel input image to a label, with an error rate of 24.6%.

is_contributed.justification: The model is used as an example within the paper but is not a contribution made by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: ResNet-50, a popular deep learning model for image classification.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not indicate that any experiments were conducted using ResNet-50, rather it serves as a theoretical example of energy consumption for deep learning models.

is_compared.justification: ResNet-50 is compared to other models like ResNet-152 in terms of energy consumption and error rate.
is_compared.quote: A less computationally efficient version, ResNet-152, requires about 11 billion FLOPs (and 150 milliseconds) per image, and obtains only a slightly better error rate of 23.0%.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep residual learning for image recognition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ResNet-50 model is attributed to the paper by He et al. in the references section.
referenced_paper_title.quote: K. He, X. Zhang, S. Ren, and J. Sun. Deep residual learning for image recognition.

name.justification: The model is used as a comparison point in terms of computational efficiency and image classification error rates.
name.quote: A less computationally efficient version, ResNet-152, requires about 11 billion FLOPs (and 150 milliseconds) per image, and obtains only a slightly better error rate of 23.0%.

is_contributed.justification: ResNet-152 is cited as a point of comparison rather than claiming any development or contribution to this model within the paper.
is_contributed.quote: A less computationally efficient version, ResNet-152.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not report any execution of ResNet-152 but rather discusses it theoretically.
is_executed.quote: A less computationally efficient version, ResNet-152.

is_compared.justification: The model is numerically compared in terms of FLOPs and error rates against other models like ResNet-50.
is_compared.quote: A less computationally efficient version, ResNet-152, requires about 11 billion FLOPs (and 150 milliseconds) per image, and obtains only a slightly better error rate of 23.0%.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep residual learning for image recognition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The ResNet-152 model is referred to the paper by He et al. in the references section.
referenced_paper_title.quote: K. He, X. Zhang, S. Ren, and J. Sun. Deep residual learning for image recognition.
